name: Reality Therapy
summary: Reality Therapy is a counseling approach that focuses on personal responsibility, choice, and present-focused problem-solving, helping clients fulfill their basic psychological needs in constructive ways.
description: Developed by psychiatrist William Glasser in the 1960s, Reality Therapy is grounded in Choice Theory, which emphasizes that human behavior is driven by attempts to satisfy five basic needs: survival, love and belonging, power, freedom, and fun. The therapy focuses on the present and future rather than dwelling on the past. It encourages clients to take responsibility for their actions, evaluate whether their current behaviors meet their needs effectively, and make better choices that align with their goals and values. The therapeutic process avoids labeling mental illness and instead emphasizes building effective relationships and practical solutions.

treatment_duration: Can extend based on client needs

contraindications: Clients unable to engage in responsibility-based discussions
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and well-tolerated; emphasis on accountability can feel challenging to some clients.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate—supported by clinical use in education, correctional facilities, and substance use programs; less robust than traditional CBT.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Research suggests benefits in reducing recidivism, improving school behavior, and supporting addiction recovery, though evidence base is smaller compared to CBT.

sections.text: Reality Therapy operates through Choice Theory, emphasizing that individuals can choose their behaviors to better satisfy their five basic needs: survival, love and belonging, power, freedom, and fun. By focusing on responsibility and present choices, the therapy encourages clients to adopt behaviors that lead to more effective fulfillment of their needs.

sections.preparation: Establish a supportive relationship and clarify the client’s needs and goals.
procedure: Explore the client’s wants and goals.
Evaluate current behaviors and whether they effectively meet needs.
Encourage responsibility by focusing on controllable choices.
Avoid focusing on symptoms or past blame.

sections.treatment_phase: Assess needs, evaluate behaviors, and plan new actions.
sections.post_session: Agree on commitments for behavioral change and relationship improvement.

ideal_candidates: Clients seeking to improve relationships and decision-making
Adolescents and adults with behavioral or motivational challenges
screening_required: Assessment of cognitive capacity, readiness for responsibility-taking

practitioner: Licensed therapists trained in Reality Therapy and Choice Theory
facility: Schools, counseling centers, outpatient clinics, correctional facilities

studies: Research supports use in educational and correctional settings to reduce disruptive behaviors.
Some evidence suggests benefits for substance use treatment and addiction recovery.
sections.limitations: Smaller evidence base compared to CBT; may not address underlying psychopathology as directly.

sections.cost_effectiveness: Moderate; can be cost-effective in school and correctional settings

lifestyle_recommendations: Focus on fulfilling basic needs constructively

sections.adolescents: Widely used in school counseling for improving responsibility and reducing behavior problems.
sections.older_adults: Can support decision-making and relationship issues.

items: Emphasizes practical problem-solving over symptom discussion.
Therapists avoid criticizing, blaming, or focusing on past failures.
Best suited for clients motivated to change behavior and take responsibility.

seo.title: Reality Therapy | Choice Theory-Based Counseling
seo.description: Reality Therapy focuses on personal responsibility, choice, and fulfilling psychological needs. Effective for addiction recovery, behavior issues, and relationship challenges.
